subject: Re: How to write effective tests?
msgSnippet: ... You forgot to mention that you wrote the section on JUnitPerf. ... It only seems like it s throughout the book :-) One Part of the book is a project
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:

> I had the pleasure of being a reviewer of Dave's upcoming book.

You forgot to mention that you wrote the section on JUnitPerf.

> He also shows you how to use JUnit extensions and other
> xUnit tools. Indeed, throughout the book he's building an
> application test-first and reaches for a variety of tools along the
> way.

It only seems like it's throughout the book :-)

One "Part" of the book is a project being done test first (~ 225
pages) that uses a lot, though not all, of the tools and techniques
discussed in the previous parts of the book.

I do pull examples from the project to illustrate concepts earlier in
the book, though.

> So it's really at least two great books in one!

Hey! Good line.. now maybe I can justify the ~550 pages! It really
does aim to be very comprehensive... apparently with good success.

For the record, I started this project last March and got the final OK
while at XP2002 (which, if you were there & noticed, was why I was so
happy the last couple days :). Anyway, a big part of the reason for
writing it was that there wasn't a comprehensive sourc of information
available... in fact when I started there wasn't anything on the
shelves on TDD, just chapters or sections in various XP books (my own
included). At that point I was unaware of Kent's book-in-progress.
BTW, I think my book makes a good followup to Kent's if you happen to
be working in Java.

Once it's out and (hopefully) you all read it, I'd really like
feedback... I'm contemplating a followup that continues by looking at
other Java technologies (this book just deals with J2SE) such as J2EE
and J2ME, maybe Jini.

Dave
Dave
